content: reaper bones or whiz kids which miniature line is best especially for
people new to the Hobby let's find out
hey guys welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts this week I am
going to be talking about miniatures actually this is the first episode in
what's gonna be a new series about miniatures and miniature painting I have
been really enjoying mini painting and collecting lately and posting a lot of
photos of my work which has led to a lot of viewers asking me to cover this topic
and at first I was very reluctant to do so there are already a lot of good
established YouTube channels teaching people how to paint miniatures and that
is not really the focus of black magic crafts I realized though that a lot of
people were asking me to do this because a lot of those channels are geared
towards people who are already good at painting and wanting to achieve higher
level results and aren't necessarily geared towards brand new beginners so
I'm going to be doing that all those questions that you're too afraid to ask
or what other people might think are stupid questions they're not before I
get to painting minis before I even get to preparing minis for paint I wanted to
talk about actually obtaining minis where are people getting all these
miniatures and which ones do you buy there are an incredible overwhelming
number of miniature lines available but I'm gonna focus this series on two
specific lines Reaper bones and Wizkid's unpainted series and the reason I'm
focusing on these two lines is because I think they are without question the best
starting point for any new collector these two lines are the most affordable
miniatures you will find they are also the most readily available
at local game stores making them the most likely ones you'll actually be able
to get in person they're both really great and they should both be used of
course though they are different and they each have their pros and cons so
I'm going to talk a little bit about each one so you kind of know what each
line is all about first let's talk about Reaper bones this line has been made
kind of famous in the community for having done several incredibly
successful Kickstarter's where people could purchase hundreds of miniatures
for very very cheap Reaper as a company makes a whole bunch of different lines
of minis including metal ones but the bones line are special because they are
affordable and they're affordable because they are made out of a soft
flexible durable white plastic actually as of recently I believe they've started
making them out of a different a little bit harder more gray plastic but I
haven't seen those in person yet and most likely what you're gonna encounter
at the store is the white Reaper bones this plastic not only makes the
miniature is much more affordable than metal ones but it also makes them a lot
more durable they can Bend they can be dropped they're not gonna snap or break
the way other metal minis or even some dents or plastic ones might making them
again really good for a new hobbyist these minis are fairly easy to paint and
don't require a lot of prep work or spray priming I'm gonna touch on the
subject of priming these minis in a future video but for now let me say
don't spray paint your Reaper bones my favorite thing about the bones line is
the incredible amount of variety available in it I don't know how many
minis are in the bones line but it's gotta be several hundred if there's a
character or monster mini that you need or want Reaper bones probably has it or
if not has a very closed stand and that will
work the amount of minis available in that line is staggering and on their
website they actually have a figure finder that's very intuitive to use that
helps you narrow down and search for specific minis by entering different
specifications one thing to note about Reaper however is that they do not own
any official licenses to the intellectual property owned by companies
like Wizards of the coast so some monsters that exist in Dungeons &
Dragons are owned by their respective companies this means that other
companies can't make those or at least can't call their minis that monster for
example the beholder or the umber Hulk those IP those intellectual properties
belong to wizards so Reaper does not make a beholder or an umber Hulk but
they do make an eye monster they will make sort of knockoff versions
of these monsters and sometimes they're very similar in aesthetic or style to
the official versions and sometimes they're a fair bit different so that can
be a good thing or a bad thing but it's important to know that you will not find
certain things called by their proper name through Reaper overall these
sculpts on Reaper minis are quite good but I do find them sometimes to be a
little bit hefty kind of bulky and chunky and they almost look like one
solid mass but that is kind of a matter of taste it's just something that I've
noticed about them for certain types of characters it really works and for
others it doesn't work quite so much it can also make some of the poses not
really be ideal sometimes the details on the Reaper bones can be kind of muddied
or lost and difficult to paint but again they're so affordable that this is kind
of to be expected and they do always look good enough to be viewed from a few
feet away on a game table the Reaper bones line also does not come with
actual bases so if you're going to base your minis which I suggest you do and I
will cover in the next video in the series
you're gonna have to buy some separate bases now let's talk about the Wizkid's
line the whiz kids miniatures I find to often be of a nicer sculpt and quality
the details are more refined the figures are less bulky and often looking more
realistic because of it they're also cast in a stiffer plastic
which I personally prefer the feel of and this plastic is still very durable
because of the whiz kids minis are a little bit smaller in scale and the
details a little bit finer that means that picking them out as a new painter
can be a little bit more challenging than the sometimes more cartoonish style
reaper sculpts the Wizkid's line is a lot newer than the reaper ones which
means that they have a far smaller library of miniatures I'm guessing they
have 10% or less of the minis available that Reaper does what's interesting
though is that they own the licensing rights to both Dungeons & Dragons
monsters and Pathfinder monsters so that means that you can actually get all of
the official cool monsters from those games you can get an actual beholder
number halt mind flayer etc and they are going to all look just like they look in
your monster manuals where Reaper is often an artistic interpretation of a
monster these look just like you expect them to look when you see the official
artwork for them which i think is very cool a really neat thing about the
Wizkid's line is that some of the figures come with clear plastic on them
for various magical or spell effects which is really really neat the Wizkid's
line of minis also come pre primed with Vallejo primer which is a high quality
miniature paint and that's a huge bonus for new painters unlike Reaper bones the
whiz kids minis do actually come with included bases so you don't
have to purchase them separately I'm not a huge fan of the thin bases they come
with and again that's something I'm gonna talk about in the next video in
this series both of these lines are advertised as ready to paint out of the
package and that's not entirely true while you could just leave them as is
and not do any work on them and just paint them that's fine it's important to
know that both of these lines can contain a release agent from the molding
process which will make your paint not stick to them properly both lines should
be washed in soapy water and let to fully dry before painting that's very
important especially with the reaper bones lines they often have the mold
release agent on them the Wizkid's minis come pre-primed which
means in theory they shouldn't have any of this release agent but I have heard
of people still having difficulty with paint adhering but a simple wash with
soap and water will fix this and I'm gonna touch again more on the
preparation aspect of these minis in the next video in this series if you pick up
some of these models you may notice that some parts come bent both lines are
susceptible to this but have no fear both can be fixed by heating up the
parts and reshaping them back into their original state you can do this with
boiling water or with a heat gun and to a lesser degree with a hairdryer I'll
cover that more in detail later but for now don't be afraid of seeing some bent
parts when you're at the store if you are new to this hobby and you want to
get into miniature painting and miniature collecting I think both of
these lines are perfect for you and in fact I think you should try out both
both of these lines should be available in your local game store but if not you
can pick them up online on Amazon I will put some links in the description below
to the general search for both Reaper bones figures and the Wizkid's ones
those links will be my Amazon affiliate links so that will help
the channel by giving me a commission if you happen to purchase that way but
honestly for minis I think that the best place to buy them is at your local game
store it's really important that you support your local game stores and bring
them some business - especially when they are stocking cool things like these
miniatures whiz kids as far as I know does not sell directly from their own
website Reaper does and I actually do encourage you to shop through their
website because one they have the figure finder that is really useful but they
also offer free shipping of orders over a certain value and it's not a very high
value for you Canadians out there what's amazing is that they also offer free
shipping to Canada and man let me tell you that is a rare and exceptional and
exciting thing so I hope that this video has been of some use to you and that
answers some of the very basic questions about getting into this aspect of the
Hobby I am going to continue this series and I'm gonna take you from knowing
nothing to having awesome painted minis on your game table so I encourage you if
you have some questions that you would like me to answer if there's some
burning question that you just don't understand about miniature painting or
prep work put it in the comments below and I will take note of that no matter
how silly that question may seem those silly questions are perfect for this
series if you found this video useful hit that like button and if you're new
here by god hit the subscribe button I got tons of cool content that I'm sure
you will enjoy if you want to help out the channel and pick up any of the tools
and supplies that I use regularly in my builds you can head over to Blackmagic
craft CA that's where I have my essential equipment store where I link
to all of the products and tools and supplies that I stand behind and
recommend those purchases through Amazon give the channel a small Commission that
help fund these videos the other way that these videos are funded and the
reason that they continue to be made is because of the generous support of
viewers on patreon if you're not familiar with patreon I highly encourage
you to head over to my page check it out see what it's all about see how you can
help me in I can help you I need that support from
viewers to keep this channel growing strong until next week guys Cheers
happy crafting and happy gaming I got to go
be a player in curse estrade wish me luck
